subject: multiprocess server, ZMQ-based management cli tool
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-28 21:52:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/virtualbmc/commit/7cd417b4cf48ab75f6a1bcbc96dd1e471edf213d', 'message': "WIP: threading server, socket-based management cli tool

Original design of the vBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual vBMCs (via admin cli), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual vBMCs (via admin cli). The instances become
independent processes.

There were certain usage inconveniences with the original
design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/watch free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way admin communication with the vBMC instances
  what makes state check difficult

This commit attempts to turn server part of the tool into
a single process running multiple threads:

* one thread per vBMC instance
* main thread handling admin interface

The main thread is able to:

* manipulate permanent instance configuration
* spawn and tear down instances threads

Naturally, all threads die together so it's easy to manage
them all at once.

The main challenge with the new design so far is to
shutdown IPMI session clearly. Thus, WIP.

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-07-31 13:19:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/virtualbmc/commit/d433bf754f75f2dd3d52b5840f55ced68163deeb', 'message': 'WIP: multiprocess server, socket-based management cli tool

Original design of the vBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual vBMCs (via admin cli), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual vBMCs (via admin cli). The instances become
independent processes. The only way to know their
whereabouts is through the pidfiles they maintain.

There were certain usage inconveniences with the original
design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/monitor free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way communication between the parent process
  and the vBMC instances what makes child state check
  or modification unnecessary difficult

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single
process spawning multiple children processes and herding
them via IPC.

The parent process runs admin interface, maintains
persistent vBMC instances configuration and ensures
all its children are alive and kicking. Each vBMC
instance is still a separate parent fork.

If child dies, parent respawns it right away. If parent
dies, it tries its best to kill all its orphans.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
Also, having multiple processes leverages CPU-based
concurrency.

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-07-31 20:39:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/virtualbmc/commit/dfbed7d53830c06ccd2335fa8d3cb8e1265b68ef', 'message': 'WIP: multiprocess server, socket-based management cli tool

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single

Also, having multiple processes leverages CPU-based

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d
'}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2017-08-01 16:43:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/virtualbmc/commit/297f0ce582b959656244384d2836676409ac94c2', 'message': "WIP: multiprocess server, socket-based management cli tool

Original design of the vBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual vBMCs (via admin cli), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual vBMCs (via admin cli). The instances become
independent processes. The only way to know their
whereabouts is through the pidfiles they maintain.

There were certain usage inconveniences with the original
design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/monitor free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way communication between the parent process
  and the vBMC instances what makes child state check
  or modification unnecessary difficult

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single
process spawning multiple children processes and herding
them via IPC.

The parent process runs admin interface, maintains
persistent vBMC instances configuration and ensures
all its children are alive and kicking. Each vBMC
instance is still a separate parent fork.

If child dies, parent respawns it right away. If parent
dies, it tries its best to kill all its orphans.

This new implementation tries to stay compatible with
the original one in part of `vbmc` tool behaviour. Whenever
it can't connect to the `vbmcd` it tries to fork and spawn
the daemon.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
Also, having multiple processes leverages CPU-based
concurrency.

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d
"}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2017-08-01 20:15:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/virtualbmc/commit/c2e5e23119be5c792d3275593f47825042b163ea', 'message': "WIP: multiprocess server, socket-based management cli tool

Original design of the vBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual vBMCs (via admin cli), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual vBMCs (via admin cli). The instances become
independent processes. The only way to know their
whereabouts is through the pidfiles they maintain.

There were certain usage inconveniences with the original
design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/monitor free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way communication between the parent process
  and the vBMC instances what makes child state check
  or modification unnecessary difficult

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single
process spawning multiple children processes and herding
them via IPC.

The parent process runs admin interface, maintains
persistent vBMC instances configuration and ensures
all its children are alive and kicking. Each vBMC
instance is still a separate parent fork.

If child dies, parent respawns it right away. If parent
dies, it tries its best to kill all its orphans.

This new implementation tries to stay compatible with
the original one in part of `vbmc` tool CLI interface
and behaviour. Whenever it can't connect to the `vbmcd`
it tries to fork and spawn the daemon behind the scenes.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
Also, having multiple processes leverages CPU-based
concurrency.

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d

"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2017-08-02 15:53:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/virtualbmc/commit/32c8b4a564355d5a6c612ed67fd11051a4ae5c8c', 'message': "multiprocess server, socket-based management cli tool

Original design of the vBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual vBMCs (via a cli tool), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual vBMCs (via the cli tool). Then the instances
become independent processes. The only way to know their
whereabouts is through the pidfiles they maintain.

There were certain practical inconveniences with the
original design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/monitor free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way communication between the parent process
  and the vBMC instances what makes child state check
  or modification unnecessary difficult

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single
process spawning multiple children processes and herding
them via IPC (the multiprocessing module does that).

The parent process runs server part of the control interface,
maintains persistent vBMC instances configuration and ensures
all its children are alive and kicking. Each vBMC
instance is still a separate parent fork.

If child dies, parent respawns it right away. If parent
is about to die, it tries its best to kill all the
prospective orphans.

This new implementation tries to stay compatible with
the original one in part of `vbmc` tool CLI interface
and behaviour. Whenever it can't connect to the `vbmcd`
it tries to fork and spawn the daemon behind the scenes.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
The other minor consideraton is that running multiple
processes leverages CPU-based concurrency.

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d

"}, {'number': 18, 'created': '2018-03-01 12:20:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/virtualbmc/commit/76b331affcb413aa5c8452a90d93bf164ae02bdc', 'message': "multiprocess server, ZMQ-based management cli tool

Original design of the vBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual vBMCs (via a cli tool), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual vBMCs (via the cli tool). Then the instances
become independent processes. The only way to know their
whereabouts is through the pidfiles they maintain.

There were certain practical inconveniences with the
original design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/monitor free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way communication between the parent process
  and the vBMC instances what makes child state check
  or modification unnecessary difficult

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single
process spawning multiple children processes and herding
them via ZMQ client/server.

The parent process runs server part of the control
interface, maintains persistent vBMC instances
configuration and ensures all its children are alive
and kicking. Each vBMC instance is still a separate
parent fork.

If child dies, parent respawns it right away. If parent
is about to die, it tries its best to kill all the
prospective orphans.

This new implementation tries to stay compatible with
the original one in part of `vbmc` tool CLI interface
and behaviour. Whenever it can't connect to the `vbmcd`
it tries to fork and spawn the daemon behind the scenes.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,

complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
The other minor consideration is that running multiple
processes leverages CPU-based concurrency.

This new implementation tries to stay compatible with
the original one in part of `vbmc` tool CLI interface
and behaviour. Whenever it can't connect to the `vbmcd`
it tries to fork and spawn the daemon behind the scenes.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
The other minor consideration is that running multiple
processes leverages CPU-based concurrency.

Other changes:

* The `start` command now accepts more than one domains
  to be started

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d
Closes-Bug: #1751570
"}, {'number': 23, 'created': '2018-03-12 15:34:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/virtualbmc/commit/4c06455a87d5eac4161d69a5b14fd192b0eea57c', 'message': "multiprocess server, ZMQ-based management cli tool

Original design of the vBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual vBMCs (via a cli tool), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual vBMCs (via the cli tool). Then the instances
become independent processes. The only way to know their
whereabouts is through the pidfiles they maintain.

There were certain practical inconveniences with the
original design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/monitor free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way communication between the parent process
  and the vBMC instances what makes child state check
  or modification unnecessary difficult

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single
process spawning multiple children processes and herding
them via ZMQ client/server.

The parent process runs server part of the control
interface, maintains persistent vBMC instances
configuration and ensures all its children are alive
and kicking. Each vBMC instance is still a separate
parent fork.

If child dies, parent respawns it right away. If parent
is about to die, it tries its best to kill all the
prospective orphans.

This new implementation tries to stay compatible with
the original one in part of `vbmc` tool CLI interface
and behaviour. Whenever it can't connect to the `vbmcd`
it tries to fork and spawn the daemon behind the scenes.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
The other minor consideration is that running multiple
processes leverages CPU-based concurrency.

Other changes:

* The `start` command now accepts more than one domains
  to be started

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d
Closes-Bug: #1751570

commit_message:
multiprocess server, ZMQ-based management cli tool

Original design of the VirtualBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual VirtualBMC (via a cli tool), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual VirtualBMC instances (via the cli tool). Then
the instances become independent processes. The only way
to know their whereabouts is through the pidfiles
they maintain.

There were certain practical inconveniences with the
original design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/monitor free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way communication between the parent process
  and the VirtualBMC instances what makes child state check
  or modification unnecessary difficult

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single
process spawning multiple children processes and herding
them via ZMQ client/server.

The parent process runs server part of the control
interface, maintains persistent VirtualBMC instances
configuration and ensures all its children are alive
and kicking. Each VirtualBMC instance is still a separate
parent fork.

If child dies, parent respawns it right away. If parent
is about to die, it tries its best to kill all the
prospective orphans.

This new implementation tries to stay compatible with
the original one in part of `vbmc` tool CLI interface
and behaviour. Whenever it can't connect to the `vbmcd`
it tries to fork and spawn the daemon behind the scenes.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
The other minor consideration is that running multiple
processes leverages CPU-based concurrency.

Other changes:

* The `start` command now accepts more than one domains
  to be started

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d
Story: 1751570
Task:  12057

added_lines: import os import json import socketfrom virtualbmc import log from virtualbmc import config as vbmc_config SERVER_TIMEOUT = 10 CONF = vbmc_config.get_config() LOG = log.get_logger() prog='Virtual BMC admin tool', subparsers = parser.add_subparsers(dest='command') subparsers.required = True parser_start.add_argument('domain_names', nargs='+', data_out = {attr: getattr(args, attr) for attr in dir(args) if not attr.startswith('_')} data_out = json.dumps(data_out) server_socket = CONF['default']['server_sock'] client_socket = os.path.join( os.path.dirname(server_socket), str(os.getpid()) + '.sock' ) server = socket.socket(socket.AF_UNIX, socket.SOCK_DGRAM) server.settimeout(SERVER_TIMEOUT) server.bind(client_socket) server.connect(server_socket) server.send(data_out.encode('utf-8')) data_in = server.recv(8192) server.close() except socket.error: print('Server at %(sock)s is not responding' % {'sock': server_socket}) return 1 finally: try: os.remove(client_socket) except Exception: pass try: data_in = json.loads(data_in.decode('utf-8')) except json.JSONDecodeError as ex: print('Server response parsing error %(error)s' % {'error': ex}) return 1 rc = data_in.get('rc') if rc: print('ERROR (%(rc)s): %(msg)s' % {'rc': rc, 'msg': '\n'.join(data_in.get('msg', ()))}) return 1 msg = data_in.get('msg') if msg: print('%(msg)s' % {'msg': '\n'.join(msg)}) header = data_in.get('header') if header: try: ptable = PrettyTable(header) for row in data_in.get('rows', ()): ptable.add_row(row) print(ptable.get_string(sortby=header[0])) except Exception as ex: print('Error formatting response table: %(error)s' % {'error': ex}) return rc sys.exit(main())

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that

'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I5db260ef3cdd09a5cf6b87733db34b5ad830deab

commit_message:
rerun *_init_bundles all the time

In the same spirit as change I1f07272499b419079466cf9f395fb04a082099bd
we want to rerun all pacemaker _init_bundles all the time. For a few main
reasons:
1) We will eventually support scaling-up roles that contain
   pacemaker-managed services and we need to rerun _init_bundles so that
   pacemaker properties are created for the newly added nodes.
2) When you replace a controller the pacemaker properties will be
   recreated for the newly added node.
3) We need to create appropriate iptables rules whenever we add a
   service to an existing deployment.

We do this by adding the DeployIdentifier to the environment so that
paunch will retrigger a run at every redeploy.

Partial-Bug: #1775196
Change-Id: Ifd48d74507609fc7f4abc269b61b2868bfbc9272
(cherry picked from commit a0dfc6c0c694091eae195d4090a63e339f3daa39)

commit_message:
replace windows line endings with unix line endings

The python 3 version of the linter does not allow Windows-style line
endings (\r\n) so replace them with UNIX-style endings (\n).

Change-Id: Ifb97491323d3df92bb1520e373552aeb5e1919a4
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Make Ironic devstack simulation less dependent on OVS

The VM simulation is heavily tied to the neutron deployment using OVS.

This patch adds additional configuration steps that mean that we can now
run neutron in either LB or OVS modes with out affecting the simulation.

Change-Id: I0a7cf018cd0cf7463fa361a1fb6f6fc79a49c1f0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/21/440721/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: elif [[ "$Q_AGENT" == "linuxbridge" ]]; then ironic_configure_neutron_ironic_lb die $LINENO "Unsupported neutron Q_AGENT only openvswitch or linuxbridge are supported by the Ironic devstack plugin."function ironic_configure_neutron_ironic_lb { # Append interface mappings here to ensure that we don't affect anything # that the neutron devstack plugin has done. if [[ -z "$LB_INTERFACE_MAPPINGS" ]]; then LB_INTERFACE_MAPPINGS="$IRONIC_PHYSICAL_NETWORK:$IRONIC_PHYSICAL_INTERFACE" else LB_INTERFACE_MAPPINGS+=",$IRONIC_PHYSICAL_NETWORK:$IRONIC_PHYSICAL_INTERFACE" fi iniset /$Q_PLUGIN_CONF_FILE linux_bridge physical_interface_mappings $LB_INTERFACE_MAPPINGS }
deleted_lines: die $LINENO "Unsupported neutron Q_AGENT only openvswitch is supported."

commit_message:
Handle multinode VXLAN tunnel inside ironic devstack plugin

For our devstack plugin to work out of the box for multinode we should
handle the configuration of the VXLAN tunnel between the nodes in our
devstack plugin instead of in devstack-gate.

Change-Id: I04172200464abc4e486ae85a655176bf230d953e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/18/440718/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Connect multinode bmswitchs together with a tunnel to simulate a single physical network # We use a VXLAN tunnel because some CI node providers don't allow GRE if [[ "$HOST_TOPOLOGY_ROLE" == "primary" ]]; then local id for node in $HOST_TOPOLOGY_SUBNODES; do id=$(echo $node | cut -d '.' -f 4) sudo ip link add bmswdown$id type vxlan id 1 remote $node local $HOST_IP dstport 4789 sudo ip link set bmswdown$id up ironic_add_port_to_virtual_switch $IRONIC_VM_NETWORK_BRIDGE bmswdown$id flat done elif [[ "$HOST_TOPOLOGY_ROLE" == "subnode" ]]; then sudo ip link add bmswitchup type vxlan id 1 remote $SERVICE_HOST local $HOST_IP dstport 4789 sudo ip link set bmswitchup up ironic_add_port_to_virtual_switch $IRONIC_VM_NETWORK_BRIDGE bmswitchup flat fi
deleted_lines: sudo ovs-vsctl add-port $IRONIC_VM_NETWORK_BRIDGE phy-brbm-vxlan sudo ovs-vsctl add-port br_ironic_vxlan phy-vxlan-brbm sudo ovs-vsctl set interface phy-brbm-vxlan type=patch sudo ovs-vsctl set interface phy-vxlan-brbm type=patch sudo ovs-vsctl set interface phy-vxlan-brbm options:peer=phy-brbm-vxlan sudo ovs-vsctl set interface phy-brbm-vxlan options:peer=phy-vxlan-brbm

revisions:

This patch ensures that we source the Ironic devstack plugin from the

commit_message:
Grenade source correct Ironic devstack plugin version

This patch ensures that we source the Ironic devstack plugin from the
version of devstack that was used to setup the devstack environment
preventing any future changes to the devstack plugin from breaking the
upgrade process.

Change-Id: I7b017827fb0bf3f7bddd92d469955c739eae6d30
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/17/440717/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: source $TOP_DIR/../ironic/devstack/lib/ironic

subject: Rework Ironic devstack baremetal network simulation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-02 20:38:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/62f61bb5c33434b09fe669f8c2bae34f8d7848ad', 'message': "Rework Ironic devstack baremetal network simulation

This patch replaces the existing devstack logic for simulating virtual
baremetals attached to a virtual network. The existing logic is heavily
tied to the neutron deployment using OVS.

The new logic isolates the simulated network, using linux bridge and
vEth devices, letting neutron treat it like a real physical network.
This means that we can now run neutron in either LB or OVS modes and it
doesn't affect our simulation.

Additionally we can now simulate a statically configured VLAN network,
as an alternative to a flat network. With some additional changes in
networking-generic-switch multiple isolated tenant networks will be
supported.

For a visual representation of an example topology that would exist in
this simulated environment look here: https://goo.gl/Ab0e3R

In order to make this work several old ironic devstack variables have
been removed, and a few new ones added. The variables that exist for
tweaking simulated network configuration should be reusable to enhance
our devstack plugin's support for real hardware scenarios.

Change-Id: I7384f026d845f07bcd421f68f6b806fd64cd95ac

"}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2016-11-08 20:22:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/b962645945c406371216216124f1688ec6b4bfc5', 'message': "Rework Ironic devstack baremetal network simulation

This patch replaces the existing devstack logic for simulating virtual
baremetals attached to a virtual network. The existing logic is heavily
tied to the neutron deployment using OVS.

The new logic isolates the simulated network, using linux bridge and
vEth devices, letting neutron treat it like a real physical network.
This means that we can now run neutron in either LB or OVS modes and it
doesn't affect our simulation.

Additionally we can now simulate a statically configured VLAN network,
as an alternative to a flat network. With some additional changes in
networking-generic-switch multiple isolated tenant networks will be
supported.

For a visual representation of an example topology that would exist in
this simulated environment look here: https://goo.gl/Ab0e3R

This change also makes the devstack ironic neutron configuration work
for cases when IRONIC_IS_HARDWARE=True, configuring real interfaces for
use with the neutron networks.

In order to make this work several old ironic devstack variables have
been removed, and a few new ones added.

Change-Id: I7384f026d845f07bcd421f68f6b806fd64cd95ac

use with the neutron networks.

In order to make this work several old ironic devstack variables have
been removed, and a few new ones added.

New development documentation has been added to describe why and how we
create a simulated baremetal environment.

Change-Id: I7384f026d845f07bcd421f68f6b806fd64cd95ac
Depends-On: I7790cd6750630d6bb8ffbe9ca1eb066760d06475
Depends-On: I6475788aa230bbdb048425d9c1b51404d59a1bef
Depends-On: I560dc41106b16dc1a19ae80248af82b552c96358
"}, {'number': 22, 'created': '2017-01-18 11:48:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/d3233e90ebf5dee7fb0364fcb5929cdc96feb69f', 'message': "Rework Ironic devstack baremetal network simulation

This patch replaces the existing devstack logic for simulating virtual
baremetals attached to a virtual network. The existing logic is heavily
tied to the neutron deployment using OVS.

The new logic isolates the simulated network, using linux bridge and
vEth devices, letting neutron treat it like a real physical network.
This means that we can now run neutron in either LB or OVS modes and it
doesn't affect our simulation.

Additionally we can now simulate a statically configured VLAN network,
as an alternative to a flat network. With some additional changes in
networking-generic-switch multiple isolated tenant networks will be
supported.

This change also makes the devstack ironic neutron configuration work
for cases when IRONIC_IS_HARDWARE=True, configuring real interfaces for
use with the neutron networks.

In order to make this work several old ironic devstack variables have
been removed, and a few new ones added.

New development documentation has been added to describe why and how we
create a simulated baremetal environment.

Change-Id: I7384f026d845f07bcd421f68f6b806fd64cd95ac
Depends-On: I7790cd6750630d6bb8ffbe9ca1eb066760d06475
Depends-On: I6475788aa230bbdb048425d9c1b51404d59a1bef
Depends-On: I560dc41106b16dc1a19ae80248af82b552c96358

commit_message:
Rework Ironic devstack baremetal network simulation

This patch replaces the existing devstack logic for simulating virtual
baremetals attached to a virtual network. The new logic isolates the
simulated environment from the neutron deployment so that the simulation
appears as a physical network to Neutron.

This change also makes the devstack ironic neutron configuration work
for cases when IRONIC_IS_HARDWARE=True, configuring real interfaces for
use with the neutron networks.

In order to make this work several old ironic devstack variables have
been removed, and a few new ones added.

New development documentation has been added to describe why and how we
create a simulated baremetal environment.

Change-Id: I7384f026d845f07bcd421f68f6b806fd64cd95ac
Depends-On: I6475788aa230bbdb048425d9c1b51404d59a1bef
Depends-On: I560dc41106b16dc1a19ae80248af82b552c96358
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/59/392959/37 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --bridge $BRIDGE --disk-format $DISK_FORMAT $VM_LOGGING --engine $ENGINE $vm_opts >&2
deleted_lines: # Create bridge and add VM interface to it. # Additional interface will be added to this bridge and # it will be plugged to OVS. # This is needed in order to have interface in OVS even # when VM is in shutdown state sudo brctl addbr br-$NAME sudo ip link set br-$NAME up sudo ovs-vsctl add-port $BRIDGE ovs-$NAME -- set Interface ovs-$NAME type=internal sudo ip link set ovs-$NAME up sudo brctl addif br-$NAME ovs-$NAME --bridge br-$NAME --disk-format $DISK_FORMAT $VM_LOGGING --engine $ENGINE $vm_opts >&2

subject: [WIP][DNM] Experiment with batch through iptables-restore

Instead of making hundreds of requests to iptables, we can use
iptables-restore to batch load new rules into iptables.

commit_message:
[WIP][DNM] Experiment with batch through iptables-restore

Instead of making hundreds of requests to iptables, we can use
iptables-restore to batch load new rules into iptables.

Change-Id: Icfa268654347f4405d53504065847c6fda57a6e6

commit_message:
Correcting url in action_plan policy

url in action_plan policy file is:
'path': '/v1/action_plans/{action_plan_uuid}/action'
whereas it shouls be :
'path': '/v1/action_plans/{action_plan_uuid}/start'

Related-Bug: #1756274

Change-Id: Ic15fed9af739b59efb2777b70514697747b2af7f

commit_message:
Allow config_template to be loaded as a role

Currently when this repo loaded as a role instead of copied to
plugins paths, config_template tasks fail because:
FAILED! => {"msg": "module (config_template) is missing interpreter line"}

This is because ansible searches for action plugins in the action_plugins/
path of roles and plays instead of action/. See
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.5/plugins/action.html#enabling-action-plugins
for information on this.

By simply symlinking action_plugins -> action we can make this work
in either scenario.

Change-Id: I59625e358e220b83d4a2580ac5f99bc11751ebdd

commit_message:
Doc: Remove -r option for running a specific unit test

Now that os-testr was replaced with stestr for running unit tests, -r
options is no longer necessary to pass a regex to the test runner.

Change-Id: I2d3738e3af47a4a01db3223941e07e68537b5a5c

deleted_lines: To run a specific unit test, this passes the -r option and desired test (regex string) to `os-testr <https://pypi.org/project/os-testr>`_:: tox -epy27 -- -r test_conductor

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I3c8e5c663a3fd881430f84fc502e46192de77fc7

commit_message:
Cap hacking at 1.2.0

In commit 02ece7fc9f133d41972e977d900e2411166be550 hacking
was capped at version 1.1.0 to fix gate issue.

Change I6c76a43353b1beb572dbde78dba4b4a839d45ea7 fixes
the issues with new rules and new defaults in hacking 1.2.0.

Story: 2001985
Task: 22104
Change-Id: Ib912724e83090a72d5c97c6bb2cb41b935265fdb

commit_message:
Prometheus datasource

The datasource currently supports notifications from
Prometheus.

There are a few related tasks that will be handled in
future commits:

1. Prometheus may send the ip of the instance instead
   of its name. We need to find a way (in the
   transformer)to identify the correct instance in
   the graph.

2. The 'vitrage event post' API should be changed so
   it can handle events from Prometheus.

3. Need to implement get_all in the datasource

Change-Id: Id1cba3e060b70c232891a34bf6793c185a074a7b
Depends-On: Ide6906ee477aa7df9ab0918d3b45a7001afdcf74
Implements: blueprint prometheus-datasource

commit_message:
undercloud: manage mysql user + revoke grant during upgrade

This task is done when bootstraping a new deployment but we also need to
run these commands when upgrading the containerized undercloud so
healthcheck can run mysql commands from mysql user.

Change-Id: Ie77785caba0a1fb8e2058a998b21cc88bc666fd7
Closes-Bug: #1776570
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/86/575186/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1776570 - name: Manage mysql user for healthcheck and revoke grant shell: > mysql -e "CREATE USER IF NOT EXISTS \`mysql\`@\`localhost\`;" mysql -e "REVOKE ALL PRIVILEGES, GRANT OPTION FROM \`mysql\`@\`localhost\`;" become: true when: - step|int == 2 - {get_param: UndercloudUpgrade}

commit_message:
Fix standalone ip configuration

Also add notes how to create a clouds.yaml for osc usage.

Change-Id: If0caaaacadcf0a40b8580c2d3bb56a068687fa0c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/39/575239/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: export NETMASK=24 $NETWORK.0/$NETMASK: - $NETWORK.0/$NETMASK NetworkCidr: $NETWORK.0/$NETMASK --local-ip=$IP/$NETMASK \ export ADMIN_PASS=$(egrep "^[[:space:]]+AdminPassword:" $HOME/tripleo-undercloud-passwords.yaml | awk '{print $2}')#. Create clouds.yaml for use with openstackclient You can create a clouds.yaml which allows you to use the openstackclient:: mkdir -p ~/.config/openstack cat <<EOF >~/.config/openstack/clouds.yaml clouds: standalone: auth: auth_url: http://$IP:5000/ project_name: admin username: admin password: $ADMIN_PASS region_name: regionOne identity_api_version: 3 EOF export OS_CLOUD=standalone openstack endpoint list

role for 'member', and 'member' as an implied role for 'admin'.

commit_message:
Ensure default roles created during bootstrap

Expand bootstrap process to include creation of roles outlined in
basic default roles spec.

The bootstrap process now creates two new roles, 'reader' and 'member,
in addition to the well established 'admin' role. During this process,
a role implication[1] chain is created: 'admin' implies 'member' and
'member' implies 'reader'.

[1] - https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/#create-role-inference-rule

Co-Authored-By: Juan Antonio Osorio Robles <jaosorior@redhat.com>
bp basic-default-roles
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/574149
Change-Id: Ie18a269e3d1075d955fe494acaf634a393c6bd7b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/43/572243/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.reader_role_id = None # TODO(hrybacki): port this to config self.reader_role_name = 'reader' self.member_role_id = None # TODO(hrybacki): port this to config self.member_role_name = 'member' self._bootstrap_reader_role() self._bootstrap_member_role() def _bootstrap_reader_role(self): # NOTE(morganfainberg): Do not create the role if it already exists. try: role_id = uuid.uuid4().hex role = {'name': self.reader_role_name, 'id': role_id} role = PROVIDERS.role_api.create_role(role_id, role) LOG.info('Created role %s', self.reader_role_name) except exception.Conflict: LOG.info( 'Role %s exists, skipping creation.', self.reader_role_name ) # NOTE(davechen): There is no backend method to get the role # by name, so build the hints to list the roles and filter by # name instead. hints = driver_hints.Hints() hints.add_filter('name', self.reader_role_name) role = PROVIDERS.role_api.list_roles(hints)[0] self.reader_role_id = role['id'] def _bootstrap_member_role(self): # NOTE(morganfainberg): Do not create the role if it already exists. try: role_id = uuid.uuid4().hex role = {'name': self.member_role_name, 'id': role_id} role = PROVIDERS.role_api.create_role(role_id, role) LOG.info('Created role %s', self.member_role_name) # TODO(hrybacki): locate provider api to create implied role & update except exception.Conflict: LOG.info( 'Role %s exists, skipping creation.', self.member_role_name ) # NOTE(davechen): There is no backend method to get the role # by name, so build the hints to list the roles and filter by # name instead. hints = driver_hints.Hints() hints.add_filter('name', self.member_role_name) role = PROVIDERS.role_api.list_roles(hints)[0] # TODO(hrybacki): check for role implication, add, & update self.member_role_id = role['id'] # TODO(hrybacki): locate provider api to create implied role & updat # TODO(hrybacki): check for role implication, add, & update enabled

subject: Fix ansible tmp dir to mistral working directory
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-06-15 09:30:01.000000000', 'files': ['tripleo_common/actions/ansible.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/4944d2184d6f8969a9ebe8d991f23c5fb5ea843d', 'message': 'Fix ansible tmp dir to mistral working directory

It normally uses $HOME that is set to the mistral working directory
already , but for some reason it stopped working in my environment and
tries to write a directory in /home/mistral/.ansible/tmp/. The strange
thing is that there is
a /var/lib/mistral/config-download-latest/.ansible/tmp/ directory too.

Change-Id: Ib18f82f6b50d114880e4fc22e716c44898cfba89
'}]
commit_message:
Fix ansible tmp dir to mistral working directory

It normally uses $HOME that is set to the mistral working directory
already , but for some reason it stopped working in my environment and
tries to write a directory in /home/mistral/.ansible/tmp/. The strange
thing is that there is
a /var/lib/mistral/config-download-latest/.ansible/tmp/ directory too.

Change-Id: Ib18f82f6b50d114880e4fc22e716c44898cfba89
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/03/575703/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: config.set('defaults', 'remote_tmp', os.path.join(work_dir, '.ansible', 'tmp')) config.set('defaults', 'local_tmp', os.path.join(work_dir, '.ansible', 'tmp'))

commit_message:
Fix the file name of development-environment.rst

In Ideb50626e140201dded19fc82584440f1a407e47,
the path of development-environment.rst has been fixed
in doc/README.rst. But the file name was not fixed.

Fix the file name of development-environment.rst
in doc/README.rst.

TrivialFix

commit_message:
DisposableWatch for k8s client

Add object that frees all the resources of the watch
(file descriptor and connection).

This allows to close watch threads without resource leaking.
This is required for network-policy handler that adds and
removes watches on networkpolicy events.The watch thread
can't dispose itself - because the watch could be long
time on io-wait.



Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies
Change-Id: Iafcec892e5889e711905542201a214a2727a0fd2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes refs/changes/48/543448/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import threading def send_watch_request(self, path): return requests.get(url, params=params, stream=True, cert=self.cert, verify=self.verify_server, headers=header) def watch_iter_response(self, response): if not response.ok: raise exc.K8sClientException(response.text) for line in response.iter_lines(delimiter='\n'): line = line.strip() if line: yield jsonutils.loads(line) def watch(self, path): resp = self.send_watch_request(path) with contextlib.closing(resp) as response: yield self.watch_iter_response(response) class DisposableWatch(object): def __init__(self, k8s_client, path): self.client = k8s_client self.path = path self.lock = threading.Lock() self.response = None self.stopped = False def watch(self): # TODO(ivc): handle connection errors and retry on failure while not self.stopped: self.lock.lock() self.response = self.k8s_client.send_watch_request(self.path) self.lock.unlock() self.k8s_client.watch_iter_response(self.response) if self.response is not None: self.response.close def dispose(self): self.lock.lock() self.stopped = True self.response.raw.close() self.response = None self.lock.unlock()
deleted_lines: def watch(self, path): with contextlib.closing( requests.get(url, params=params, stream=True, cert=self.cert, verify=self.verify_server, headers=header)) as response: if not response.ok: raise exc.K8sClientException(response.text) for line in response.iter_lines(delimiter='\n'): line = line.strip() if line: yield jsonutils.loads(line)

commit_message:
Annotate pods that selected by k8s label-selector

Set a watch on each selector in the policy -
and annotate the pods with the relevant security-group.

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies

Change-Id: I3d121dbfde36fe20f95648cea03c7e97f490f4c2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes refs/changes/63/545663/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Create network policy handler and driver

This patch adds watch on network policy events.
At this stage the watch will create a security-group that
corresponds to the network-policy but the security group will not
be attached to any port.

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies
Parent:     6c86b930 (Translate k8s policy to SG)

Change-Id: I8df683da09decd8a4a4d3e58a61d71d451d2aa0d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes refs/changes/55/530655/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_log import log as logging from kuryr_kubernetes import constants as k_const from kuryr_kubernetes.controller.drivers import base as drivers from kuryr_kubernetes.handlers import k8s_base LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class PolicyHandler(k8s_base.ResourceEventHandler): OBJECT_KIND = k_const.K8S_OBJ_POLICY def __init__(self): self.policy_driver = drivers.PolicyDriver.get_instance() def on_added(self, policy): self.policy_driver.build_policy(policy) def on_deleted(self, policy): self.policy_driver.delete_policy(policy) def on_modified(self, policy): self.policy_driver.update_policy(policy)

commit_message:
Add policy security-groups driver

The driver reads the sg annotaions and updates the port respectively.

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies

Change-Id: I4aa47913503c3a0e04f3067b92d11fe45f641804
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes refs/changes/72/545872/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: K8S_ANNOTATION_VIF_APPLIED_SG = K8S_ANNOTATION_PREFIX + 'applied-vif-sg'

commit_message:
Translate k8s policy to SG

This patch contains a module that translates k8s-network-policy
to neutron-security-groups. The input for this module is the
network-policy.json and it's translates it to security-groups-rules
and apply it by neutron client.

In this patch the module still not connected to any driver.

This is the first work-item in order to support k8s
Network-policy (work-item-list described in the blueprint).

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies
Change-Id: I0c1b85a8a363ab42685c9922b08811f8c99bce94
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes refs/changes/16/526916/32 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2016 Mirantis, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from kubernetes import client import netaddr from kuryr_kubernetes import clients DIRECTION_INGRESS = 'ingress' DIRECTION_EGRESS = 'egress' SG_FIELD_REMOTE_IP = 'remote_ip_prefix' SG_FIELD_REMOTE_GROUP = 'remote_group_id' SG_FIELD_PORT_RANGE_MIN = 'port_range_min' SG_FIELD_PORT_RANGE_MAX = 'port_range_max' SG_FIELD_PROTOCOL = 'sg_field_protocol' SG_FIELD_DIRECTION = 'direction' SG_FIELD_ETH_TYPE = 'ethertype' SG_FIELDS_SG_UID = 'security_group_id' SG_IPV4 = 'IPv4' SG_GROUP_RULE = 'security_group_rule' SG_RULE_LIST = 'security_group_rules' SG_RULE_ID = 'id' SG = 'security_group' SG_NAME = 'name' SG_UID = 'id' def _exclude_inner_sbunets(allwoed_ip_range, exclude_list): range = netaddr.IPSet([allwoed_ip_range]) exclude = netaddr.IPSet(exclude_list) if not exclude.issubset(range): raise ValueError(_('exclude list nust be subset of range')) remain = range ^ exclude for cidr in remain.iter_cidrs(): yield cidr def _build_ip_block_sg_fields(ip_block): ret = [] expect = [] if ip_block._except is not None: expect = ip_block._except cidrs = _exclude_inner_sbunets(ip_block.cidr, expect) for cidr in cidrs: ret.append({SG_FIELD_REMOTE_IP: str(cidr)}) return ret def _build_peers_sg_field(peers): ret = [] for peer in peers: if peer.ip_block is not None: ip_block_rules = _build_ip_block_sg_fields(peer.ip_block) ret += ip_block_rules elif peer._namespace_selector is not None: # TODO(leyal) : handle namespace selector pass elif peer.pod_selector is not None: # TODO(leyal) : handle pod selector pass return ret def _get_allow_all_rule(direction): return { SG_GROUP_RULE: { SG_FIELD_DIRECTION: direction, } } def _build_ports_sg_fields(ports): ret = [] for port in ports: # If l3_proto not specified it's tcp l3_porto = port.protocol if port.protocol else 'TCP' port_and_porto = {SG_FIELD_PROTOCOL: l3_porto} # if port not specified allow all ports if port.port: port_and_porto[SG_FIELD_PORT_RANGE_MIN] = port.port port_and_porto[SG_FIELD_PORT_RANGE_MAX] = port.port ret.append(port_and_porto) return ret def _create_sg(name=None, tags=None): client = clients.get_neutron_client() sg_object = {} if name is not None: sg_object.update(name) response = client.create_security_group({SG: sg_object}) sg_uid = response[SG][SG_UID] if tags is not None: for tag in tags: client.add_tag(SG, sg_uid, tags) return response[SG] def _get_policy_type_from_spec(spec): policy_types = [] if spec.policy_types is not None: for type in policy_types: # 'Ingress' to 'ingress' policy_types.append(type.lower()) else: policy_types = [DIRECTION_INGRESS] return policy_types class RemoteGroup(object): def __init__(self, tag, queries): self.group_uid = None self.queries = [] self.tags = None def create(self): # TODO(leyal) build an empty security-group pass class PeersAndPorts(object): def __init__(self): self.peers = None self.ports = None class NetworkPolicySgRules(object): def __init__(self, policy_rules, direction): self.direction = direction self.peer_and_ports = [] self.group_uid = None self._is_allow_all = False self._is_deny_all = False self._parse_rules(policy_rules) def _parse_rules(self, policy_rules): if policy_rules is None: self._is_deny_all = True return for rule in policy_rules: if self._get_peers(rule) is None or rule.ports is None: self._is_allow_all = True return for rule in policy_rules: peer_and_port = PeersAndPorts() peer_and_port.peers = _build_peers_sg_field(self._get_peers(rule)) peer_and_port.ports = _build_ports_sg_fields(rule.ports) self.peer_and_ports.append(peer_and_port) def _get_peers(self, policy_rules): if self.direction == DIRECTION_INGRESS: return policy_rules._from else: return policy_rules.to def build_rules(self, sg_uid): if self._is_allow_all: return [_get_allow_all_rule(self.direction)] # Empty security group for deny all elif self._is_deny_all: return [] else: return self._build_port_and_peers_rule(sg_uid) def _build_port_and_peers_rule(self, sg_uid): ret = [] for peer_and_port in self.peer_and_ports: for peer in peer_and_port.peers: for port in peer_and_port.ports: rule = {} rule.update(peer) rule.update(port) # TODO(leyal) support ipv6 rule.update({SG_FIELD_DIRECTION: self.direction, SG_FIELDS_SG_UID: sg_uid, SG_FIELD_ETH_TYPE: SG_IPV4}) ret.append({SG_GROUP_RULE: rule}) return ret class TempResponse(object): '''Use for deserialize the answer by k8s client''' def __init__(self, json): self.data = json class NetPolicySecuirtyGroup(object): def __init__(self, policy_json): self.policy = None self.remote_groups = None self._parse_json(TempResponse(policy_json)) self.sg_uid = None def _parse_json(self, policy_json): api_client = client.ApiClient() self.policy = api_client.deserialize(policy_json, 'V1NetworkPolicy') def _build_rule_for_direction(self, direction, spec, policy_types): # Direction not specified so allow all if direction not in policy_types: return [_get_allow_all_rule(direction)] policy_rules = getattr(spec, direction) sg_translator = NetworkPolicySgRules(policy_rules, direction) return sg_translator.build_rules(self.sg_uid) def _add_rules_for_direction(self, direction, spec, policy_types): client = clients.get_neutron_client() rules = self._build_rule_for_direction(direction, spec, policy_types) # TODO(leyal) check if can add all rules in one api-call for rule in rules: client.create_security_group_rule(rule) def _add_sg_rules(self): spec = self.policy.spec policy_types = _get_policy_type_from_spec(spec) for direction in [DIRECTION_INGRESS, DIRECTION_EGRESS]: self._add_rules_for_direction(direction, spec, policy_types) def _clean_default_sg_rules(self, sg): # Neutron security group came with some default rules # That not relevant to network-policy rules = sg.get(SG_GROUP_RULE, []) # TODO(leyal) this call can be optimize if the default rules # Overlapping the policy-rules for rule in rules: rule_id = rule[SG_RULE_ID] client = clients.get_neutron_client() client.delete_security_group_rule(rule_id) def build_secuirty_group(self): sg_obj = _create_sg(tags=[self.policy.metadata.uid]) self._clean_default_sg_rules(sg_obj) self.sg_uid = sg_obj[SG_UID] self._add_sg_rules()

commit_message:
Add new schema for Nova microversion 2.63

This microversion adds the trusted_image_certificates parameter to the
server rebuild, server create, server update, and servers details
responses.

Change-Id: I48f62d36a871a95601ebf277a2f39a41a873daa8
Implements blueprint: nova-validate-certificates
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/85/526485/36 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ServerShowV257Test(base.BaseV2ComputeTest): min_microversion = '2.57' max_microversion = 'latest' @decorators.idempotent_id('71b8e3d5-11d2-494f-b917-b094a4afed3c') def test_show_server(self): server = self.create_test_server() # All fields will be checked by API schema self.servers_client.show_server(server['id'])

subject: Added scenario: MTU manipulation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-04-25 10:51:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/commit/e760fed5b0277a12db66a7196b5ca9b80d2d6158', 'message': "Added scenario: MTU manipulation

This newly added test is creating two networks
with custom MTU valus using the 'available_type_drivers'
and lets the user configure 'max_mtu', to enable
testing new scenarios like Jumbo Frames.
After creating the networks two instances are
spwned and trying to ping each other using different
values of MTU and with/without 'DO NOT FRAGMENT' flag.

Change-Id: Ica6ae26a8469bbfddfba30c9e193d40ca1cac67f

commit_message:
Added scenario: MTU manipulation

This newly added test is creating two networks
with custom MTU values using the 'available_type_drivers'
and lets the user configure 'max_mtu', to enable
testing new scenarios like Jumbo Frames.
After creating the networks two instances are
spawned and trying to ping each other using different
values of MTU and with/without 'DO NOT FRAGMENT' flag.

Change-Id: Ica6ae26a8469bbfddfba30c9e193d40ca1cac67f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin refs/changes/58/564158/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.IntOpt('max_mtu', default=1450, help='Max MTU value for networks. ' 'Configure this only when project is using non-default ' 'MTU values like Jumbo.')

commit_message:
Refactor libvirt get_memory_used_mb()

Split _sum_domain_memory_mb and _get_avail_memory_kb to separate
functions. Simplifies xen codepath in get_memory_used_mb, and eases
integration for file-backed-memory

Change-Id: Ifaa866b88a04c14fbb45bc9d8cd11e847c6dd671
Implements: blueprint libvirt-file-backed-memory
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/30/571030/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _sum_domain_memory_mb(self, host_id=None): """Get the total memory consumed by guest domains For xen, subtract available host memory from the host_id domain to get real used memory within dom0 """ used = 0 for guest in self.list_guests(only_guests=False): try: # TODO(sahid): Use get_info... dom_mem = int(guest._get_domain_info(self)[2]) except libvirt.libvirtError as e: LOG.warning("couldn't obtain the memory from domain:" " %(uuid)s, exception: %(ex)s", {"uuid": guest.uuid, "ex": e}) continue if guest.id == host_id: # Memory usage for the host domain (dom0 in xen) is the # reported memory minus available memory used += (dom_mem - self._get_avail_memory_kb()) else: used += dom_mem # Convert it to MB return used // units.Ki @staticmethod def _get_avail_memory_kb(): with open('/proc/meminfo') as fp: m = fp.read().split() idx1 = m.index('MemFree:') idx2 = m.index('Buffers:') idx3 = m.index('Cached:') avail = (int(m[idx1 + 1]) + int(m[idx2 + 1]) + int(m[idx3 + 1])) return avail if CONF.libvirt.virt_type == 'xen': # For xen, report the sum of all domains, with return self._sum_domain_memory_mb(host_id=0) else: return self.get_memory_mb_total() - \ (self._get_avail_memory_kb() // units.Ki)
deleted_lines: with open('/proc/meminfo') as fp: m = fp.read().split() idx1 = m.index('MemFree:') idx2 = m.index('Buffers:') idx3 = m.index('Cached:') if CONF.libvirt.virt_type == 'xen': used = 0 for guest in self.list_guests(only_guests=False): try: # TODO(sahid): Use get_info... dom_mem = int(guest._get_domain_info(self)[2]) except libvirt.libvirtError as e: LOG.warning("couldn't obtain the memory from domain:" " %(uuid)s, exception: %(ex)s", {"uuid": guest.uuid, "ex": e}) continue # skip dom0 if guest.id != 0: used += dom_mem else: # the mem reported by dom0 is be greater of what # it is being used used += (dom_mem - (int(m[idx1 + 1]) + int(m[idx2 + 1]) + int(m[idx3 + 1]))) # Convert it to MB return used // units.Ki else: avail = (int(m[idx1 + 1]) + int(m[idx2 + 1]) + int(m[idx3 + 1])) # Convert it to MB return self.get_memory_mb_total() - avail // units.Ki

commit_message:
Move nova cell v1 job to check pipeline

Nova cell v1 job run as experimental and it is
obvious that we miss testing the tempest changes against
this job which can leads to gate block on nova side.
One example is https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1776684

nova cell v1 is deprecated but not yet removed and this job
run on nova check and gate pipeline.

This commit moves the cell v1 job from experimental pipeline
to check pipeline on tempest side so that we can monitor it.

Once nova wil drop cell v1, Tempest can drop this job.

Change-Id: Ic01e867d590810f620b141a554a596ddd5e73fed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/93/575393/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update doc on stable release frequency

It was decided that we should release stable branches more
frequently than we are, document for future neutronians.

Fixed other typos as noticed.

Change-Id: I4fb0ca5f41a97ae99995c485f7296b7d81c4b78e

commit_message:
Fix image_id KeyError in test_create_backup

image_id is added to the result of create_backup, but it's not
added in the header, it's added in body instead, so we can't
get image_id from resp.response, otherwise it will raise
"KeyError: 'image_id'". This is to fix it.

Ref: https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#create-server-back-up-createbackup-action

Implements blueprint: clear-deprecated-api

Change-Id: If924bc417c24e5bcc18577d20023f277653d7dd3

commit_message:
Clarify docker vs moby containers runtime/images

For containerized undercloud as a good start, avoid using
references to Docker if only not limited to the docker CLI
commands.

Whenever we refer to *architecture* for containers runtime and
images (CRI & OCI), refer to Moby instead.

This creates less confusion for readers might be expecting more
features of Docker is used, like Swarm as COE, while it is not.

Eventually, this replacement should happen to all places.

Change-Id: Ia731d7a151f0a294297b0528173e36577ad0dfeb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/28/572328/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: The docker based undercloud architecture is not very different from the baremetal/VM based one. The services deployed in the traditional baremetal undercloud are also deployed in the docker based one.

Switch to using stestr

should migrate.
Let's switch it then.

commit_message:
change testrepository to stestr

As testrepository has changed to testr, dumping
logs on fullstack is spitting error.

Change-Id: Ic5e88f063e5e17408b6a565e224ef2c40e7d92c3
Co-Authored-By: Isaku Yamahata <isaku.yamahata@intel.com>
Co-Authored-By: Michel Peterson <michel@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/91/572691/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo -H -u $owner chmod o+rw -R .stestr if [ -f ".stestr/0" ] ; then $SUBUNIT1TO2 < .stestr/0 > ./stestr.subunit $SCRIPTS_DIR/subunit2html ./stestr.subunit testr_results.html gzip -9 ./stestr.subunit
deleted_lines: sudo -H -u $owner chmod o+rw -R .testrepository if [ -f ".testrepository/0" ] ; then $SUBUNIT1TO2 < .testrepository/0 > ./testrepository.subunit $SCRIPTS_DIR/subunit2html ./testrepository.subunit testr_results.html gzip -9 ./testrepository.subunit

commit_message:
More retrieval options for ODL from Nexus

Currently it only tries to retrieve the version from snaphsots, but this
is only for current supported versions. Older versions require to
retrieve them from releases.

This patch triest to retrieve it from snapshots and then, if it fails,
it tries from releases.

Change-Id: I24bd16c8a8240ba5abe0e4612380b7cc22d044f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/91/572791/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: local SNAPSHOT=${2:-true} if $SNAPSHOT ; then echo "${NEXUSPATH:-${ODL_URL_PREFIX}/${ODL_URL_SNAPSHOT_REPOSITORY_PATH}/${ODL_URL_DISTRIBUTION_KARAF_PATH}}" else echo "${NEXUSPATH:-${ODL_URL_PREFIX}/${ODL_URL_RELEASE_REPOSITORY_PATH}/${ODL_URL_DISTRIBUTION_KARAF_PATH}}" fi local SUFFIX="-SNAPSHOT" for SNAPSHOT in true false; do local NEXUSPATH=$(_odl_nexus_path $ODL_URL_PREFIX $SNAPSHOT) _wget $MAVENMETAFILE ${NEXUSPATH}/maven-metadata.xml $OFFLINE if [[ ! -r $MAVENMETAFILE ]]; then echo "$MAVENMETAFILE doesn't exist. Please try with OFFLINE=False and check internet connection to $NEXUSPATH" exit 1 fi if [[ "$MAJOR_MINOR" == "latest" ]]; then local ODL_FULL_VERSION=$(_xpath "//latest/text()" $MAVENMETAFILE) else local ODL_FULL_VERSION=$(_xpath "//version[starts-with(text(), '$MAJOR_MINOR')][last()]/text()" $MAVENMETAFILE) fi if [[ "$ODL_FULL_VERSION" == "" ]]; then if $SNAPSHOT; then echo "Version $MAJOR_MINOR not found in the SNAPSHOT URL." SUFFIX="" continue fi echo "Version $MAJOR_MINOR not found also in RELEASE URL. Exiting." exit 1 fi ODL_FULL_VERSION=$ODL_FULL_VERSION$PREFIX echo $ODL_FULL_VERSION done
deleted_lines: echo "${NEXUSPATH:-${ODL_URL_PREFIX}/${ODL_URL_SNAPSHOT_REPOSITORY_PATH}/${ODL_URL_DISTRIBUTION_KARAF_PATH}}" local NEXUSPATH=$(_odl_nexus_path $ODL_URL_PREFIX) _wget $MAVENMETAFILE ${NEXUSPATH}/maven-metadata.xml $OFFLINE if [[ ! -r $MAVENMETAFILE ]]; then echo "$MAVENMETAFILE doesn't exist. Please try with OFFLINE=False and check internet connection to $NEXUSPATH" exit 1 fi if [[ "$MAJOR_MINOR" == "latest" ]]; then local ODL_FULL_VERSION=$(_xpath "//latest/text()" $MAVENMETAFILE) else local ODL_FULL_VERSION=$(_xpath "//version[starts-with(text(), '$MAJOR_MINOR')][last()]/text()" $MAVENMETAFILE) fi ODL_FULL_VERSION=${ODL_FULL_VERSION/-SNAPSHOT/} echo $ODL_FULL_VERSION

"msgid "7.0.0.0b2-5" msgstr "7.0.0.0b2-5" msgid "" "Fixed `bug 1768824`_ which could cause the service_statuses table to be " "flooded with duplicate service entries." msgstr "" "Fixed `bug 1768824`_ which could cause the service_statuses table to be " "flooded with duplicate service entries." "If there are duplicate service entries in the service_statuses table and the " "db sync command fails, you may need to truncate the service_statuses table." msgstr "" "If there are duplicate service entries in the service_statuses table and the " "db sync command fails, you may need to truncate the service_statuses table." msgid ""msgid "" "We fixed this by introducing a new unique constraint to the service_statuses " "table." msgstr "" "We fixed this by introducing a new unique constraint to the service_statuses " "table."

subject: libvirt: Don't report DISK_GB if sharing
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-04-11 14:51:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b49d9ffa1d39990e23ce8379ed74d7c705c2ba4a', 'message': "WIP: libvirt: Don't report DISK_GB if sharing

For libvirt, if the operator wishes to use shared storage, she must
manually configure the sharing resource provider in placement and
associate it via aggregate with the compute node.  However, the libvirt
driver was still reporting the (same) DISK_GB inventory in the compute
node provider.

With this patch, we check the provider tree to see if a sharing provider
of DISK_GB is present.  If so, we don't report that inventory - because
it's already accounted for by the sharing provider.

Change-Id: Iea283322124cb35fc0bc6d25f35548621e8c8c2f
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-04-11 15:18:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/8656f7479db4dd24afc67d5f5bf217f45d118e45', 'message': "WIP: libvirt: Don't report DISK_GB if sharing

For libvirt, if the operator wishes to use shared storage, she must
manually configure the sharing resource provider in placement and
associate it via aggregate with the compute node.  However, the libvirt
driver was still reporting the (same) DISK_GB inventory in the compute
node provider.

With this patch, we check the provider tree to see if a sharing provider
of DISK_GB is present.  If so, we don't report that inventory - because
it's already accounted for by the sharing provider.

Change-Id: Iea283322124cb35fc0bc6d25f35548621e8c8c2f

commit_message:
libvirt: Don't report DISK_GB if sharing

For libvirt, if the operator wishes to use shared storage, they must
manually configure the sharing resource provider in placement and
associate it via aggregate with the compute node.  However, the libvirt
driver was still reporting the (same) DISK_GB inventory in the compute
node provider.

With this patch, we check the provider tree to see if a sharing provider
of DISK_GB is present.  If so, we don't report that inventory - because
it's already accounted for by the sharing provider.

Co-Authored-By: Bhagyashri Shewale <bhagyashri.shewale@nttdata.com>
Closes-Bug: #1771728
Change-Id: Iea283322124cb35fc0bc6d25f35548621e8c8c2f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/59/560459/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import os_traits def _has_sharing_provider(self, provider_tree, resource_class): """Returns whether the specified provider_tree contains any sharing providers of inventory of the specified resource_class. """ for rp_uuid in provider_tree.get_provider_uuids(): pdata = provider_tree.data(rp_uuid).data() has_rc = resource_class in pdata.inventory is_sharing = os_traits.MISC_SHARES_VIA_AGGREGATE in pdata.traits if has_rc and is_sharing: return True return False } # If a sharing DISK_GB provider exists in the provider tree, then our # storage is shared, and we should not report the DISK_GB inventory in # the compute node provider. if not self._has_sharing_provider(provider_tree, rc_fields.ResourceClass.DISK_GB): result[rc_fields.ResourceClass.DISK_GB] = { }

Add split-stack environment support.

Upgrading split-stack(pre-provisioned) environments requires some
extra steps/options to be added/applied.

commit_message:
Move L3 agent checks inside overcloud upgrade script.

Currently L3 agent checks are called from ansible tasks,
 though those scripts already exist at uc.
Current change calls those scripts from within `upgrade` script,
 which makes it easier for local reproducing.

Change-Id: Ib3a781f570155a2139b6e0cf3debfc97363c6a08

Ml2DvrDBTestCase.

commit_message:
Fix undefined update_containers variable

When checking for update_containers var we need to check if it's
defined at all. Also all booleans should be with |bool

Closes-Bug: #1777261
Change-Id: Ied1ea6f6f0656b182a6b29fd1b69fc5596ac5f28
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras refs/changes/92/575992/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: when: update_containers and update_containers_append_tag is undefined

commit_message:
Modify novaclient to support basic attributes

Added support for parsing OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_ID, OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME,
OS_USER_DOMAIN_ID, and OS_USER_DOMAIN_NAME options.

Change-Id: I9e1a3426f174c2e6d9f4f6bf10e9aecb62bad8d0

commit_message:
Add reserved status key word to horizon

Horizon don't have related change which align with the
change in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/330285.
With this fix, horizon can work as expected

Change-Id: I5940c662a0bec2beaf4863e07f7244311ba51212

Signed-off-by: GUO Larry <guo1017138@163.com>

commit_message:
[Stable Only] Initialise failed_builds in IronicNodeState

When we merged I71c56fe770f8c3f66db97fa542fdfdf2b9865fb8 we introduced a
regression in the ironic host manager as it doesn't setup a
failed_builds attribute.  We didn't need to do this on master as the
host manager in question is already removed due to
I695b250c82c8dcedcd8e2bee00c56bb2df19212c

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/575132/
Change-Id: Ia52dda42208398b4f719fa3023dd10d9642b1e02
Closes-Bug: 1776596
(cherry picked from commit d26dc0ca03e9cc9a04ac02d88ba2d2867340f5cd)

subject: Make @memoize thread-aware
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-06-04 08:37:50.000000000', 'files': ['horizon/utils/memoized.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/0de6c6a06f87573392f4beac1b41d07401548ba5', 'message': "Make @memoize thread-aware

If 2 parallel threads simultaneously make an expensive call to a
memoized function with arguments for which the returned value wasn's
cached before, 2 calls are effectively made in parallel.

It's better to avoid such a situation and if one thread already
initiated an expensive call, block on it in another thread and once
the call in the first thread is completed, unblock and reuse the value
which is cached now.

Co-Authored-By: Vladislav Kuzmin <vkuzmin@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: Id216e7b9c1bd836ee70a36ecb378e7d51d3821d2
(cherry picked from commit a72a1eca6e495fb033926f41369f7389e81a9f2d)
"}]
commit_message:
Make @memoize thread-aware

If 2 parallel threads simultaneously make an expensive call to a
memoized function with arguments for which the returned value wasn's
cached before, 2 calls are effectively made in parallel.

It's better to avoid such a situation and if one thread already
initiated an expensive call, block on it in another thread and once
the call in the first thread is completed, unblock and reuse the value
which is cached now.

Co-Authored-By: Vladislav Kuzmin <vkuzmin@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: Id216e7b9c1bd836ee70a36ecb378e7d51d3821d2
(cherry picked from commit a72a1eca6e495fb033926f41369f7389e81a9f2d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/49/572049/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import collectionsimport threading locks = collections.defaultdict(threading.Lock) del locks[key] with locks[key]: try: # We want cache hit to be as fast as possible, and don't # really care much about the speed of a cache miss, because # it will only happen once and likely calls some external # API, database, or some other slow thing. That's why the # hit is in straightforward code, and the miss is in an # exception. value = cache[key] except KeyError: value = cache[key] = func(*args, **kwargs) except TypeError: # The calculated key may be unhashable when an unhashable # object, such as a list, is passed as one of the arguments. In # that case, we can't cache anything and simply always call the # decorated function. "The key %r is not hashable and cannot be memoized." % (key,), UnhashableKeyWarning, 2)
deleted_lines: # We want cache hit to be as fast as possible, and don't really # care much about the speed of a cache miss, because it will only # happen once and likely calls some external API, database, or # some other slow thing. That's why the hit is in straightforward # code, and the miss is in an exception. value = cache[key] except KeyError: value = cache[key] = func(*args, **kwargs) except TypeError: # The calculated key may be unhashable when an unhashable object, # such as a list, is passed as one of the arguments. In that case, # we can't cache anything and simply always call the decorated # function. "The key %r is not hashable and cannot be memoized." % (key,), UnhashableKeyWarning, 2)

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I7a1bddaba707626c1c84d0e325360e72115d9ef2

commit_message:
Remove nova dependencies from test_resource_provider

Now, none of the tests in test_resource_provider.py require
anything from the nova base test class, so testtools.TestCase is
used instead.

Also, the request context provided by placement (intead of nova)
is more appropriate for these tests (and doesn't require a CONF)

Because the DatabasePoisonFixture is no longer present we no longer
need the mock in AllocationTest that guards against it.

Change-Id: I62d348e4551cce7a93337e32eb540574d8291bd2

commit_message:
Move db using provider unit tests to functional

Some of the ResourceProvider unit tests used the db directly.

These have been moved to the functional test_resource_provider.py and
transformed as required to make them work in that setting. Some test
cases were appended to existing tests where it made sense.

The save_immutable test which claimed to use the db, but did not,
remains in the original file but in a more suitable test class.

Change-Id: I7a91ed797b052500fdd80690cb35f1049ef6c422
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/80/572280/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_save_immutable(self): fields = { 'id': 1, 'uuid': _RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID, 'generation': 1, 'root_provider_uuid': _RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID, } for field in fields: rp = resource_provider.ResourceProvider(context=self.context) setattr(rp, field, fields[field]) self.assertRaises(exception.ObjectActionError, rp.save)

test_create_no_parent(self): rp = resource_provider.ResourceProvider( self.context, uuid=_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID, name=_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_NAME) rp.create() self.assertIsInstance(rp.id, int) self.assertEqual(_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID, rp.uuid) self.assertEqual(_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_NAME, rp.name) self.assertEqual(_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID, rp.root_provider_uuid) self.assertIsNone(rp.parent_provider_uuid) def test_create_in_db_with_parent_provider_uuid(self): parent = resource_provider.ResourceProvider( self.context, uuid=uuids.parent, name="parent") parent.create() child = resource_provider.ResourceProvider( self.context, uuid=uuids.child, name="child", parent_provider_uuid=uuids.parent) child.create() self.assertEqual(uuids.child, child.uuid) self.assertEqual(uuids.parent, child.parent_provider_uuid) self.assertEqual(uuids.parent, child.root_provider_uuid) def test_save_immutable(self): fields = { 'id': 1, 'uuid': _RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID, 'generation': 1, 'root_provider_uuid': _RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID, } for field in fields: rp = resource_provider.ResourceProvider(context=self.context) setattr(rp, field, fields[field]) self.assertRaises(exception.ObjectActionError, rp.save) def test_get_by_uuid_from_db(self): rp = resource_provider.ResourceProvider(context=self.context, uuid=_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID, name=_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_NAME) rp.create() retrieved_rp = resource_provider.ResourceProvider.get_by_uuid( self.context, _RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID) self.assertEqual(rp.uuid, retrieved_rp.uuid) self.assertEqual(rp.name, retrieved_rp.name) self.assertEqual(rp.root_provider_uuid, retrieved_rp.root_provider_uuid) def test_get_by_uuid_from_db_missing(self): self.assertRaises(exception.NotFound, resource_provider.ResourceProvider.get_by_uuid, self.context, uuids.missing) def test_destroy_with_traits(self): """Test deleting a resource provider that has a trait successfully. """ rp = resource_provider.ResourceProvider(self.context, uuid=uuids.rp, name='fake_rp1') rp.create() custom_trait = resource_provider.Trait(self.context, uuid=uuids.trait, name='CUSTOM_TRAIT_1') custom_trait.create() rp.set_traits([custom_trait]) trl = resource_provider.TraitList.get_all_by_resource_provider( self.context, rp) self.assertEqual(1, len(trl)) # Delete a resource provider that has a trait assosiation. rp.destroy() # Assert the record has been deleted # in 'resource_provider_traits' table # after Resource Provider object has been destroyed. trl = resource_provider.TraitList.get_all_by_resource_provider( self.context, rp) self.assertEqual(0, len(trl)) # Assert that NotFound exception is raised. self.assertRaises(exception.NotFound, resource_provider.ResourceProvider.get_by_uuid, self.context, uuids.rp) def test_destroy(self): def emulate_rp_mysql_delete(func): def wrapped(context, _id): rp = context.session.query( models.ResourceProvider).\ filter( models.ResourceProvider.id == _id).first() self.assertIsNone(rp.root_provider_id) return func(context, _id) return wrapped emulated = emulate_rp_mysql_delete(resource_provider._delete_rp_record) rp = resource_provider.ResourceProvider( self.context, uuid=_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID, name=_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_NAME) rp.create() with mock.patch.object( resource_provider, '_delete_rp_record', emulated): rp.destroy()

commit_message:
Adjust db using allocation unit tests

Some of the Allocation unit tests used the db directly.

Two were already duplicated by existing functional tests,
so were removed. test_create_with_id_fails doesn't need
the db if simplified and provided with some mocks for code
called but not used.

Change-Id: If1be243813079065e975a7d3983398e03df22a6d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/81/572281/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # FIXME(cdent): Tests which use the database aren't unit tests. class TestAllocation(_TestCase): USES_DB = True @mock.patch('nova.api.openstack.placement.objects.resource_provider.' '_ensure_rc_cache', side_effect=_fake_ensure_cache) def test_create(self, mock_ensure_cache): rp = resource_provider.ResourceProvider(context=self.context, uuid=_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID, name=_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_NAME) rp.create() inv = resource_provider.Inventory(context=self.context, resource_provider=rp, resource_class=_RESOURCE_CLASS_NAME, total=16, reserved=2, min_unit=1, max_unit=8, step_size=1, allocation_ratio=1.0) inv_list = resource_provider.InventoryList(context=self.context, objects=[inv]) rp.set_inventory(inv_list) obj = resource_provider.Allocation(context=self.context, resource_provider=rp, resource_class=_RESOURCE_CLASS_NAME, consumer_id=uuids.fake_instance, used=8) alloc_list = resource_provider.AllocationList(self.context, objects=[obj]) alloc_list.create_all() rp_al = resource_provider.AllocationList saved_allocations = rp_al.get_all_by_resource_provider( self.context, rp) self.assertEqual(1, len(saved_allocations)) self.assertEqual(obj.used, saved_allocations[0].used) def test_create_with_id_fails(self): rp = resource_provider.ResourceProvider(context=self.context, uuid=_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID, name=_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_NAME) rp.create() inv = resource_provider.Inventory(context=self.context, resource_provider=rp, resource_class=_RESOURCE_CLASS_NAME, total=16, reserved=2, min_unit=1, max_unit=8, step_size=1, allocation_ratio=1.0) inv_list = resource_provider.InventoryList(context=self.context, objects=[inv]) rp.set_inventory(inv_list) obj = resource_provider.Allocation(context=self.context, id=99, resource_provider=rp, resource_class=_RESOURCE_CLASS_NAME, consumer_id=uuids.fake_instance, used=8) alloc_list = resource_provider.AllocationList(self.context, objects=[obj]) self.assertRaises(exception.ObjectActionError, alloc_list.create_all) def test_create_exceed_capacity_fails(self): rp = resource_provider.ResourceProvider(context=self.context, uuid=_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID, name=_RESOURCE_PROVIDER_NAME) rp.create() inv = resource_provider.Inventory(context=self.context, resource_provider=rp, resource_class=_RESOURCE_CLASS_NAME, total=16, reserved=2, min_unit=1, max_unit=16, step_size=1, allocation_ratio=1.0) inv_list = resource_provider.InventoryList(context=self.context, objects=[inv]) rp.set_inventory(inv_list) obj = resource_provider.Allocation(context=self.context, resource_provider=rp, resource_class=_RESOURCE_CLASS_NAME, consumer_id=uuids.fake_instance, used=16) alloc_list = resource_provider.AllocationList(self.context, objects=[obj]) self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidAllocationCapacityExceeded, alloc_list.create_all)

commit_message:
Dynamic dependencies: remove unused variable

This PS removes an unused variable from the resolution of
dynamic pod dependencies.

Change-Id: I95728a7b91d5143c2a44566179ef8066727020af
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

commit_message:
Add "hot_template_version" to dynamically support multiple
HOT template version

This patch adds "hot_template_version" in "metadata", that lets
users can choose which version of HOT template they want.

Change-Id: I45609f41a1e1e01acf73abf2fb65b2ecb7cb7e86

commit_message:
Gotpl: remove quote and trunc to suppress output

This PS removes the use of the `quote and truncate` approach to
suppress output from gotpl actions in templates and replaces it
with the recommended practice of defining `$_` instead.

Change-Id: I5fedc3471dcbecef37d2fe1302bf9760b3163467
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>
